document: Chapter 1: Overview - Computer Security: Principles and Practice, 4th Edition

questions.question: Computer security is defined by NISTIR 7298 as measures that ensure confidentiality, integrity, and availability.
A threat is a weakness in an information system that can be exploited.
An adversary is also known as a threat agent.
Passive attacks alter system resources or affect their operation.
Active attacks include eavesdropping and traffic analysis.
A vulnerability is any circumstance with the potential to adversely impact organizational operations.
NIST is a United Nations agency responsible for global telecom standards.
ISO is a nongovernmental organization that publishes International Standards.
A security policy defines and constrains activities to maintain security for systems and data.
Assets of a computer system include only hardware and software.
An insider attack is initiated from outside the security perimeter.
RFC 2828 provides a glossary of internet security terms.
Attack surface categories are part of fundamental security design principles.
ITU-T is a professional membership society for Internet infrastructure standards.
Risk is a function of adverse impacts and likelihood of occurrence.
A countermeasure aims to enhance the effectiveness of adversarial activities.
Traffic analysis is a type of active attack.
FIPS 200 lists security requirements for federal information systems.
Loss of integrity means information is leaked to unauthorized parties.
The Internet Society (ISOC) is the home for groups responsible for Internet infrastructure standards.
